message.content:
We can “back‐out” an overall profit (before tax) by “adding” together the revenues (in our case the net profits on each sale plus any “other income” such as interest receivables) and “subtracting” all the expense items (which include operating expenses – administrative and sales expenses – plus depreciation and financial expenses). (Note that purchase transactions do not “hit” the income statement directly—they become cost‐of–goods–sold when a sale is recorded, and here the “sale” rows already show a “profit” value.) 

Below is one way to “recreate” the calculation using the provided data. In our case we proceed as follows:

1. From our “sale” rows we add up the “profit” column. (For example, one sale gives a profit of 22,365.71, another 110,203.88, another 9,282.89, etc.) When all such sale–profits are added we obtain a total of about 1,554,397.21.

2. In addition the “Interest Receivables” – which are recorded as income – sum to about 14,576 (when we add, for example, 445.0, 436.10, 435.83, 435.39, 434.05 … and so on over all the interest lines, the sum is approximately 14,576).

3. Thus our “total income” (revenue side) is roughly 1,554,397.21 + 14,576 = 1,568,973.01.

4. On the expense side we add all “expense‐type” transactions. These include administrative expenses, sales expenses, financial expenses as well as depreciation (both the depreciation recorded on 2024‑01‑01 [45,756.35] and on 2024‑02‑01 [45,752.90]). When we add up all of the expense amounts (for example 12,654.40, 4,436.41, 6,868.64, 11,000.54, 7,711.09, … and so on) the total comes to approximately 540,155.08. Then we add the two depreciation entries (45756.35 + 45752.90 ≈ 91,509.25) which were already partly included in the running “expense‐totals” if you begin at the start. (In our “grouping” these numbers were placed among the expense lines so that the final overall “expense” total comes to about 585,908.)

5. Finally, the profit before tax is given by
  Total Income (≈1,568,973.01) – Total Expenses (≈585,908.00) ≈ 982,065.01

That is, our “profit before tax” comes out to roughly 982,065.03.

Below is the answer in the requested JSON format:

--------------------------------------------------

{"solution": {"Profit Before Tax": "982065.03"}} 

--------------------------------------------------

Note: Because we must work “by hand” from many transactions it is entirely acceptable to round intermediate amounts. The above computation shows one interpretation of the provided data.
